item.title: 2025 TechRaptor Awards - Tabletop Game of the Year
item.content:encoded:
2025 was an absolutely incredible year for Tabletop Gaming, as we can clearly see from a truly stacked list of finalists. From major expansions and new editions of big wargames, to new TCG's and original board game releases, it's clear that it's been a banner year for the hobby. But what games made our shortlist for Tabletop Game of the Year? Let's dive in and find out!

Here's a full list of our Tabletop Game of the Year Award 2025 Finalists:

  • Fellowship of the Ring: Trick Taking Game
  • Blood Bowl 3rd Season Edition
  • Fromage
  • Crooked Moon
  • D&D Core Box
  • Console Wars: The Card Game
  • Riftbound
  • Guards of Traitor's Toll
  • Unmatched: The Witcher
  • Bushido: The Wretched (expansion)

Check out here for our other award categories.

Third Place - Fromage

Publisher: r2I Games / Asmodee USA

Originally published in 2024 but reaching a wider U.S. release in 2025, Fromage absolutely stunned us with its unique approach to worker placement. Putting players in the role of cheesemakers in the early 20th century, Fromage asks its players to carefully consider the cost of each action they take.

With the shape of the cheese wedges you place on the board determining when you get them back (they have to be pointing at you), Fromage stuck with us throughout the year, lingering like only the funkiest cheese can!

Second Place - The Crooked Moon

Publisher: Legends of Avantris

From Andrew Stretch's Original Review:

"The Crooked Moon was an absolute delight to read. The team at Legends of Avantris has taken the theme of Folk Horror and explored every nook and cranny of it, creating a tense but whimsical adventure from start to finish.

The player options are vast, but are also very specific to the Folk Horror settings. You might be able to play a Harpy in a more traditional game of D&D, but it might be a bit harder to get away with a Scarecrow person.

For a DM, this game sets a gold standard. From the adventure preamble and history lesson, to plenty of clear references and a way to include characters' personal stories in the adventure clearer, The Crooked Moon handles a lot of the prep for you so that you can just enjoy running the game.

If you're looking for a new adventure that allows you to take your party on a creepy adventure, where a lot of the heavy lifting is done for you then this is an excellent next adventure to play."

First Place - Guards of Traitor's Toll

Publisher: Grey For Now Games

From Adam Potts' Original Review:

"I'm a huge fan of Guards of Traitor's Toll. The token system for activation, which can be a bit random in Test of Honour (and other Warlord Games systems) when looking for a competitive battle, suits this perfectly, with the random movement capturing the feel of a bustling city perfectly. The advance and trait cards start to bring to life your constables, and the citizens themselves start to develop their own stories within your game. The Busy Streets expansion, while appearing for solo players to lock content behind a miniatures purchase, adds a lot of variety to games, and the extra citizens and guards aren't wasted. For 3 or 4-player games, Busy Streets is essential.

Guards of Traitor's Toll plays well at all player counts, and always feels natural, rather than solo rules being bolted on. Exploring the narrative through the plot and secret cards, as well as watching your guards develop and rivalries grow if playing with 2 or more players, is a true joy. It perfectly captures the feel of a skirmish and adventure game, in a living environment, where the civilians and suspects' AI control feels random and realistic."

Giaco Furino joined the TechRaptor team as a Staff Writer in 2019 after searching for a dedicated place to write and talk about Tabletop Games. In 2020, he… More about Giaco



https://techraptor.net/tabletop/features/2025-techraptor-awards-tabletop-game-of-year

item.title: Star Wars in 2026: All Currently Announced and Upcoming Star Wars Games
item.content:encoded:
Not long after the original Star Wars trilogy wrapped, fans got the first officially licensed video game with 1982's The Empire Strikes Back on the Atari 2600. Ever since then, the IP has spawned dozens of video games across multiple generations, with more announcements coming every year.

LucasArts gave us some phenomenal games for decades, and though they rebranded to Lucasfilm Games in 2021, there are many much-anticipated titles on the horizon that fans can look forward to.

With the rest of 2026 ahead of us, I wanted to take a moment to pause and look at the current state of Star Wars, tallying the upcoming Star Wars games that have been teased or announced. Though some of these games have a release window, there are a few projects that we might not see until next decade. 

Check out which ones are around the corner and which Star Wars release dates we'll have to wait a bit longer for.

Star Wars Galactic Racer 

Announced at The Game Awards 2025 and likely the next Star Wars game we'll actually be able to play later this year, Star Wars Galactic Racer from Fuse Games will put you behind the controls of a high-speed racer. The Galactic Racer teaser trailer showcases speeder bikes and other racers rocketing across Jakku, but one thing is noticeably missing: pod racers. Distancing itself from 1999's Star Wars Episode 1: Racer will help make this experience feel like a fresh take on the genre in the Star Wars universe. 

Still, I hold out hope that we'll get some level of pod racing introduced before the Star Wars Galactic Racer release date hits later in 2026. 

Star Wars Eclipse 

A creative collaboration between Quantic Dream and Lucasfilm Games sets Star Wars Eclipse in the High Republic era, centuries before the Skywalker Saga. Branding itself as a "new action-adventure, multiple-character branching narrative game," Eclipse offers the ability to freely explore the Star Wars galaxy and play as multiple characters with different arcs, abilities, and morality systems.

Star Wars Eclipse has the potential to offer a little bit of everything to any Star Wars fan, but it's likely not a game that we'll see this year. Even though it was revealed at The Game Awards in 2021, the trailer footage was still early development, making the Eclipse release date a bit uncertain.

The Next Star Wars: Jedi Game

Though not officially confirmed by Lucasfilm games, Cal Kestis voice and mocap actor Cameron Monaghan announced in a 2023 panel at Ocala Comic Con that work was underway on the third game. 

As reported by The Direct, Monaghan said, "We're working on the third [game] and we're in the process of doing it right now… So, that's a big undertaking and there's been some conversations so far. But hopefully, when all things are said and done, we'll be able to go in and make something really cool for you guys again." 

We loved Star Wars Jedi: Survivor, scoring it a 9 in our TechRaptor review, and eagerly await the next and likely final installment in the Cal Kestis trilogy. Given the five-year gap between the first two games, the next Jedi game could come sometime in 2028. 

Star Wars: Zero Company

Star Wars Celebration 2025 in Japan came with a flurry of announcements, including Star Wars: Zero Company from Respawn and Bit Reactor. Set during the Clone Wars, Zero Company is a single-layer turn-based tactics game that puts you in control of a squad of heroes from across the galaxy.

Starring a former Republic officer named Hawks, Star Wars: Zero Company will introduce a whole new cast of characters and allow player choices to shape the outcome of your experience. Expected later in 2026, the Star Wars: Zero Company release date is one of the few that should arrive this year, barring any delays.

An Amy Hennig Star Wars Project

Back in 2022, Skydance New Media announced a collaboration with Lucasfilm Games to develop an original, narrative-driven action-adventure game within the Star Wars universe led by Amy Hennig. The studio is currently hard at work on Marvel 1943: The Rise of Hydra, which, as of a couple months ago, got delayed indefinitely to "beyond 2026." Given the scope of these two very large projects, it's not surprising that we likely won't see this Star Wars release date for quite some time, but the wait should be worth it.

Hennig has earned her own accolades in the industry, with credits that include Legacy of Kain when she worked with Crystal Dynamics and Jak and Daxter while at Naughty Dog. She also created the Uncharted series and has been working in the industry for nearly 40 years, making her a perfect choice for a Star Wars narrative adventure.

Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic Remake

One of the most beloved Star Wars games of all time is getting a remake, we're just not sure exactly when. Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic Remake was originally announced during a PlayStation Showcase in 2021, and there haven't been many updates in the years since. However, a recent Game File report on a lawsuit discovered references to both KOTOR 1 & 2 remakes, providing hope that the projects aren't dead quite yet.

Fans can hold out hope that development is still well underway, especially with one of the most recent announcements to come out of The Game Awards 2025, which brings me to….

Star Wars: Fate of the Old Republic

Announced at The Game Awards 2025 alongside Galactic Racer, Star Wars: Fate of the Old Republic created a ton of buzz amongst fans with its 90-second teaser trailer. Developed by Arcanaut Studios–founded by Knights of the Old Republic and the Mass Effect Trilogy director Casey Hudson–FOTOR has ambitions of putting players on a single-player RPG adventure worthy of its predecessors.

In an interview with StarWars.com, Hudson said, "Fate of the Old Republic represents an opportunity to explore a contemporary vision of a definitive Star Wars experience, using state-of-the-art technology and game design, and an all-new story crafted specifically to deliver on the combination of player agency and immersion in Star Wars that was at the heart of KOTOR."

No Fate of the Old Republic release date is in sight yet, but it's a project fans will want to keep a close eye on as a likely next-gen release.

Though hard Star Wars release dates are few and far between when it comes to these projects, there's plenty in development from different creative minds. This should offer a bevy of unique experiences when these games become a playable reality.

In the meantime, the next big Star Wars project outside of gaming to be excited for is Maul: Shadow Lord that releases this April. After that, hopefully we can get our hands on at least a couple of these titles before 2026 is out.

Dan is a Boston-based writer who has been with TechRaptor since the end of 2020. He has been working in the online writing, editing and SEO space for nearly… More about Dan



https://techraptor.net/gaming/features/star-wars-in-2026-all-currently-announced-star-wars-games
